statement.text: Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta (REBOA) is a minimally invasive technique for temporary aortic occlusion in patients with life-threatening non-compressible torso hemorrhage. A balloon catheter inserted via the femoral artery is positioned in Zone 1 (descending thoracic aorta, for abdominal hemorrhage) or Zone 3 (infrarenal aorta, for pelvic hemorrhage) and inflated to occlude aortic flow, thereby reducing distal hemorrhage and augmenting central perfusion. REBOA serves as a bridge to definitive surgical or endovascular control, not as definitive treatment.
statement.formal: REBOA: Femoral artery access → Balloon catheter to Zone 1 (T4-diaphragm) or Zone 3 (below renals) → Temporary aortic occlusion → Bridge to definitive hemorrhage control. Maximum occlusion time: 60-90 minutes (Zone 1) or longer (Zone 3).

explanation.intuition: Think of REBOA as temporarily pinching the main water pipe upstream of a leak. By stopping flow above the leak site, you reduce the flooding (bleeding) and maintain water pressure to the areas above (heart, brain). But you can't pinch the pipe forever - the areas below (kidneys, intestines, legs) are being deprived of water. REBOA buys time to fix the leak but must be followed quickly by definitive repair.
explanation.key_insight: REBOA occupies the niche between resuscitation and surgery for the crashing trauma patient. It provides the physiologic support of aortic cross-clamping without the need for emergent thoracotomy or laparotomy. However, it is a temporizing measure with significant ischemic consequences, and its role is to provide a bridge to definitive hemorrhage control, not to replace it.
explanation.technical_details: REBOA is inserted via common femoral artery access (typically 7-12 Fr sheath) using ultrasound or palpation guidance. The catheter is advanced to the appropriate zone based on suspected hemorrhage location. Zone 1 extends from the origin of the left subclavian artery to the celiac trunk (for abdominal hemorrhage); Zone 2 is the paravisceral segment (avoided); Zone 3 extends from the lowest renal artery to the aortic bifurcation (for pelvic hemorrhage). External landmarks estimate catheter length. Balloon inflation provides immediate hemodynamic support, but continuous occlusion causes distal ischemia. Partial REBOA (intermittent or partial inflation) may extend safe occlusion time.

primary: Traumatic non-compressible torso hemorrhage with hemodynamic instability
patient_selection: Injury below the diaphragm (Zone 1) or pelvis (Zone 3)
Definitive care available within occlusion time limit

absolute: Traumatic aortic injury proximal to balloon position
Injury proximal to Zone 1 (arch or ascending aorta)
relative: Known aortic aneurysm at target zone
Injury with prolonged prehospital time (ischemic burden)

zone_1.location: Descending thoracic aorta (left subclavian to celiac trunk)
zone_1.indication: Abdominal hemorrhage (liver, spleen, major abdominal vessels)
zone_1.ischemic_burden: High - occludes visceral and renal perfusion

zone_2.indication: AVOID - balloon would be unstable, partial occlusion
zone_2.note: Should not deploy balloon in Zone 2

zone_3.ischemic_burden: Lower - preserves visceral and renal perfusion

technique.confirmation: Fluoroscopy if available, otherwise external landmarks
technique.inflation: Slow inflation with saline, observe BP response
technique.monitoring: Continuous BP, assess for balloon migration

distal: Potential for reperfusion injury upon deflation

outcomes.hemodynamic_effect: Immediate increase in proximal BP in 80-90% of patients
outcomes.survival: Bridge to repair - survival depends on definitive treatment success
outcomes.ischemic_complications: Proportional to occlusion time and zone

learning_objectives: Define the zones of aortic occlusion and their indications
Describe the technique of REBOA insertion
Understand the physiologic effects of aortic occlusion
Recognize the time constraints and complications of REBOA
Apply REBOA as a bridge to definitive hemorrhage control
clinical_pearls: REBOA is a BRIDGE to definitive care, not definitive treatment
Zone 1 = abdominal hemorrhage; Zone 3 = pelvic hemorrhage; Zone 2 = avoid
Zone 1 occlusion causes visceral and renal ischemia - limit to 60-90 minutes
Zone 3 preserves renal and visceral perfusion - longer tolerance
Prepare for reperfusion syndrome (hyperkalemia, acidosis) upon deflation
External landmarks: umbilicus = L4, xiphoid = T10

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of iliac artery with temporary aortic balloon occlusion
